title: Friday, 27th January, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:01am

PM11:01am

11:07 am
PM11:08am

Key takeaways
Bottom-line: investors continue to position for reflation via TIPS over munis, HY over gold & Japan over US equities.
But the re-positioning feels grudging and flows have yet to show big asset allocation capitulation out of bonds into stocks.
Weekly flows show largest bond inflows in 4 months ($8.6bn), tiny equity inflows ($0.2bn) & precious metal outflows ($0.2bn).

PM11:08am

re-positioning feels grudging -- sums it up

undefined
11:08 am
PM11:09am

And so to Tesco

PM11:09am

I am amazed at the market reaction

PM11:09am

Celebration

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Hm.

PM11:09am

I don't see how this can go through

PM11:09am

But maybe back up for a moment

11:09 am
PM11:09am

http://www.investe...1701270700082907V/

BE11:10am

The assumption is that it'll go through with big disposals, most likely on the convenience side.

PM11:10am

hmm

11:11 am
BE11:11am

But anyway. The price response this morning seems to be based on the view of what Booker will do for Tesco, rather than what Tesco might do for Booker.

PM11:11am

What, allowing it to squeeze X proportion of the small store / restaurant sectors ?

BE11:12am

No, not really.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

It kinda starts with the "weak underbelly" theory that we've been banging on here about forever.

BE11:12am

As in, the big four grocers have only ever grown by taking share from the weak independents.

BE11:13am

That growth is expended, partly due to CMA but also because Aldi etc have become the price setters and Tesco etc can't use their scale advantage any more.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

So .... Tesco buys the wholesale supplier to much of the weak underbelly! It's perfect.

BE11:13am

Except it's not.

BE11:14am

Because Booker's not priced on current sales, it's priced on its ability to roll up its current market.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

It's the leanest operator out there in a very fragmented, mostly underfunded and limping wholesale sector.

BE11:15am

(Excuse my use of 2014 data here -- I was late this morning.)

BE11:15am

11:15 am
BE11:15am

(Thatis pre Booker's acquisition of Marko, which quadrupled its depot fleet.)

PM11:15am

Interesting

PM11:15am

(Makro rather)

11:16 am
BE11:16am

So -- Booker has scale advantage, supplier support and a strong balance sheet with no particular CMA limits stopping it grazing on its weak competitors.

BE11:17am

Tesco doesn't have that. Because it's Tesco.

PM11:17am

It's a retailer

11:17 am
PM11:17am

Not a wholesaler

PM11:17am

So what are we saying here -- that Tesco can use Booker to hoover up the wholesale sector?

PM11:18am

Because that shouldn't "delight the customer" as Tesco seems to be claiming this morning

11:18 am
BE11:18am

I'm saying that was a big part of what was in Booker's valuation. If Tesco's plan is to extract that value by following Booker's pre-existing gameplan, I dunno. There may be problems.

PM11:18am

How many competition probes have their been into the supermarkets

PM11:19am

It's a straight question

11:19 am
PM11:19am

All i know is that there seems to have been a probe underway for much of my adult life

PM11:19am

There's gonna be a stink over this

PM11:19am

A real stink

11:19 am
BE11:19am

The data are fiendishly complicated. This is the best chart I could find this morning for convenience store market share.

BE11:19am

BE11:20am

That's Goldman. You can tell because the various indistinct shades of blue.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

"Symbol" is fascia-type operators, by the way. Spar or whatever.

BE11:20am

Note also that while we talk about Booker as a cash & carry, its catering side is the highly profitable bit.

BE11:20am

As in about 30% of Booker sales but about c60% of profits.

11:20 am
BE11:21am

Another indistinct-blue chart. Booker sales by sector over the past decade.

BE11:21am

BE11:22am

Difficult to see what edge Tesco has in the catering side.

11:21 am
BE11:22am

So ... is Tesco paying 25 times earnings for a company with the likelihood of turning it into a 15 times earnings-type company?

PM11:22am

(Boncoeur -- EPFR Global supplier, but they guard the data and it's $$$)

PM11:22am

25 times earnings !?!!?!

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Yes! Though there's some cash to minus from that. Anyway, is the big benefit on the logistics cost savings?

BE11:23am

You'll remember a few weeks ago that Tesco in-sourced its warehouse operations. That now looks significant, in retrospect.

BE11:23am

They're aiming for £200m of synergies by year three. £200m!

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Big number, epic execution risk.

PM11:24am

I getting even more bemused by the market reaction to this. It can only be down to what bankers call "improved market structure"

PM11:25am

Which = monopolistic power

11:24 am
BE11:25am

Oh, and part of the bump in Tesco's price this morning is restarting the divi a year earlier.

BE11:25am

One could see this as a wee bit cynical in terms of getting investors onside, given the acquisition isn't even supposed to be earnings accretive until year two.

BE11:25am

Anyway, I've typed enough. Have some people who are paid to look as this stuff rationally.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Morgan Stanley.

BE11:25am

This transaction will allow Tesco to gain exposure to faster growing food channels and should be ~5% accretive to FY18e EPS as per our calculations. These benefits, in our view, should be partially offset by the negative effects of diversification and potential antitrust hurdles.

BE11:25am

From a financial standpoint: Tesco's offers values Booker at ~16x current year EBITDA. Prior to the transaction being announced, Booker was trading on 14x, the top end of the 8x-14x range in the foodservice sector in Europe and in the US (peer group includes Sligro in the NL, Metro, Eurocash, Sysco, US Foodservice, PFGC, etc.). As of yesterday, based on consensus estimates, Tesco was trading on 9x EBITDA for the current year.

The transaction will be paid as 42.6p of cash and 0.861 of Tesco shares per Booker share (so ~20% in cash and ~80% in shares). Tesco is indicating that synergies will amount to £200m by the end of year 3 (mostly buying and logistics) and one-off costs should amount to £145m. On these assumptions (which we find sensible), due to the high proportion of the transaction being paid in Tesco shares, EPS accretion should amount to ~5% in Year 1 of the effective merger (using the run-rate for synergies). Should the deal be completed sooner however, accretion would stand closer to ~7%.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

Potential issues:
1) In foodservice, the pursuit of synergies, particularly buying synergies, could lead to Tesco/Booker's customer proposition becoming less attractive to the banners' respective customers as households and restaurants needs are materially different. This has been one of the key reason, in our view, why Metro lost focus in its domestic German market over the past 15 years.

2) Anti-trust hurdles, while certainly not insurmountable, could slow down the approval of the transaction and thus create uncertainties and distractions as the CMA will likely take time to approve the transaction. We estimate Tesco and Booker's (ex foodservice) respective market share at 28% and ~3% in the grocery sector.

3) Management changes. In the release, Tesco mentions that Charles Wilson (Booker's CEO and an 8% shareholder) will join the Tesco executive committee. Mr Wilson has been instrumental in the Booker turnaround since 2008 and, should he decide to leave the Tesco group at a latter date, that could be perceived negatively by the market.

BE11:26am

Goldman

BE11:26am

What does it all mean?
Key early takeaways for us:
1) The £200mn proposed synergies are just under 10% of the combined £1.9bn EBIT that we forecast for both companies in FY20.

2) On a trailing 12m basis, £3.7bn would put the proposed Booker price at 10.1x EV/EBIT (Booker reported FY16 EBIT of £155mn, net cash of £128mn)

3) Synergy extraction could come from distribution network optimisation and also right-sizing and re-formatting the store estate. Putting Tesco’s buying scale behind Booker would also be key.

4) Charles Wilson, Booker CEO, will be locked into his Tesco shareholding for five years and be on the Tesco Executive Board. We believe this is key for Booker’s shareholders.

5) We consider this a negative read for Sainsbury’s and Morrison, given the increased scale and operational capability of the proposed entity.

11:26 am
PM11:26am

The sellside are always suspect when it comes to evaluating deals that push competition policy to the limits. They are too conflicted - like Tesco will be all over the place if this deal goes through

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

PM11:27am

This will cause a stink. You watch

11:27 am
BE11:27am

As I say, though, measuring the 30% rule is pretty bloody fiendish.

PM11:29am

If you go back through the old Competition Commission reports they use all sorts of granular measures -- yes it is v complicated.

BE11:29am

Booker only has about 5% of the "delivered wholesale" market, which is much bigger than cash & carry, for instance. But what's the share for its customers + Tesco? I've no idea. I don't even know how to start measuring that.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Have Jefferies.

BE11:29am

This is a remarkable, unexpected deal, and one that sees TSCO buy a much-loved business in a bid to expand into wholesale. The deal will help leverage at TSCO given the large equity component, and the addition of Charles Wilson to the TSCO team will be well received. Still, this is an expensive acquisition (17.5x EV/EBITDA pre and 8.8x post synergies), and investors will want reassurance that the underlying TSCO standalone margin case remains strong.

BE11:29am

And Peel Hunt, which is going for a counterbid.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

The combined group will be a powerful combination, given improved buying power and reach in retail and foodservice, and giving opportunities to improve distribution efficiencies and customer service. Synergies are estimated to be c£200m, of which a significant proportion is likely to come from suppliers. The profit uplift equates to c14% enhancement to the combined operating profit.

Charles Wilson joins Tesco’s board and has a five-year lock-in on his shares. We believe the deal to be skinny for Booker shareholders, given the limited premium and the relatively small percentage that Booker shareholders will have of the combined group. This is likely to encourage others to look at Booker.

The CMA will inevitably crawl all over the deal, particularly given the greater share in the convenience market. However, we believe the deal is likely to pass given that it should be seen as positive for the combined group’s customers.

At 205p, the shares trade on a PE of 23.5x to March 2018E and yield 4% (including capital return of c£60m). We would recommend shareholders to hold on to see whether Tesco needs to increase its offer or if others consider an offer. We suspect that Tesco will be keen to complete this deal, so there is every chance
of a bid battle.

BE11:29am

And Shore, which isn't.

BE11:30am

We do need to reflect on this surprise deal but we think that we shall have time to do so. The regulatory process will be lively and needs to be heeded; it will definitely be a Phase II process to our minds. We are not opposed to the combination in principle albeit does not move a dial for us with respect to Tesco in a strategic
sense (note: Booker’s previous merger experience with Iceland), causing us concern about distraction in fact, but it
does concern us that Booker stock could net, net be de-rated. Hence, following this update we suggest that Booker
shareholders, many of whom held the stock because it was not a leveraged supermarket (indeed some long of
Booker have been short of Tesco), may wish to SELL into any mark up. Hence, we reiterate our HOLD stance on
Tesco and downgrade Booker shares from Hold to SELL.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Oh! Prices. That's what we're here for.

Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 205.55, up 16.55 (+8.76%), High: 209.90, Low: 188.86, Volume: 85.58m
Booker Group PLC (BOK:LSE): Last: 212.80, up 29.7 (+16.22%), High: 214.60, Low: 182.98, Volume: 49.93m

Restaurant Group PLC (RTN:LSE): Last: 287.20, down 6.5 (-2.21%), High: 297.10, Low: 285.10, Volume: 3.37m
11:36 am

BE11:37am

There was some post-results comment around on RTN but none of it particularly interesting. Just the consensus cranking downwards post the strategic review reset.

undefined
11:38 am
BE11:38am

More interestingly perhaps, AstraZeneca leading us down.

AstraZeneca PLC (AZN:LSE): Last: 4,217, down 81 (-1.88%), High: 4,323, Low: 4,137, Volume: 2.04m
BE11:38am

More worries about Mystic.

11:38 am
BE11:39am

Post Bristol-Myers Squibb saying sales slowed for Yervoy.

BE11:40am

There's no straight readthrough here -- as in, PD-L1 antagonists vs PD-1 antagonists, ask me anything, I'm clearly an expert -- but post management departures etc at AstraZeneca's oncology side it's another reason to fret.

BE11:41am

Citi's Andrew Baum had a note out overnight ......

11:41 am
BE11:41am

We interpreted BMY’s comments on yesterday’s earnings call as an unambiguous indication from management of a diminished expectation for the role of an Opdivo Yervoy chemo free combination in the management of 1st line NSCLC (lung cancer). If neither PFS (progression free survival) nor OS (overall survival) from the Opdivo Yervoy combination show superiority to chemo in CHECKMATE 227, the potential market for PDx chemo based approaches may increase (favouring initially MRK and Roche- both with data expected in 2H 2017). We are cautious in extrapolating BMY’s commentary on Opdivo and Yervoy in 1st line NSCLC to AZN’s tremi and durva combination in MYSTIC given potentially significant molecular differences. Nonetheless, we anticipate investor expectations for AZN’s MYSTIC to be depressed. Finally, the potential demise of CTLA4 as a combination partner in 1st line NSCLC is an incremental positive chemo manufacturers Lilly (Alimta) and Celgene (Abraxane). We prefer BUY rated LLY and BMY in the US. We prefer BUY rated AZN, Roche and GSK among the EU majors.

BE11:42am

Potentially importantly, AZN’s durvalumab is a PD-L1 antagonist compared with BMY’s Opdivo, a PD-1 antagonist. Differential activity on different ligand receptor interaction may translate into material efficacy differences. PD-L1 antagonism has been implicated in improved priming as well as reversing CD8 tolerance in the tumor micro-enviroment. We doubt that tremilimumab’s lack of an effector function makes it clinically distinct from BMY’s Yervoy. We anticipate yesterday’s commentary from BMY management coupled with recent delay in MYSTIC timing and on-going senior management departures will put the stock under some pressure.

BE11:42am

See! PD-L1 antagonists vs PD-1 antagonists. AMA.

11:42 am
PM11:42am

Sheesh

BE11:43am

Thing with AstraZeneca is that we have a binary event coming up -- as in, Mystic -- in the sense that the data might be positive or negative. But the longer-term hope for IO being the revolution we were promised a couple of years ago just keeps on looking more overcooked.

undefined

PM11:44am

http://www.reuters...hain-idUSKBN15A368

PM11:44am

11:44 am

PM11:45am

PM11:45am

11:45 am
PM11:45am

Last year, multiple cases of fraud emerged in the archaic bills financing industry when it was found bills thought to have been kept in a safe were actually old newspapers, and the real documents had been used to raise margin financing.

PM11:45am

That's more believable

11:48 am

PM11:50am

PM11:52am

undefined
11:53 am
BE11:53am

Sellside wise, there's a bunch of stuff on airlines and not much else.

BE11:54am

The International Consolidated Airlines, Dirigibles and Cooperage Company PLC has been upgraded by Goldman.

International Consolidated Airlines Group SA (IAG:LSE): Last: 499.50, up 8.3 (+1.69%), High: 509.00, Low: 497.00, Volume: 4.58m
11:54 am
BE11:54am

Which'll open soon, I think, but email's playing up.

BE11:55am

Instead, have RBC being mildly more positive on the sector.

BE11:55am

Upgrade IAG to sector perform - “UK GDP is better than we expected since we set IAG forecasts and as outlook is more positive, our Underperform rating has been wrong. We reflect this, and tighter 2017 Atlantic seat outlook, and move to SP. We note that in a wider fuel-led 2018E fare recovery, we see equity upside gearing being higher, GDP input risk lower for Lufthansa.”
Cut price target on EasyJet – “We have a sense of déjà-vu with easyJet. Post Q1 outlook implies a significant H2 profit recovery that looks optimistic to us. We think this likely means another (summer) profit cut to come. We stay Underperform, but see that as a potential trigger to revisit and perhaps revise a position.”
Wizz Air Holdings – “We see Wizz profits slowing in Q3 (due 01/02/2017) and 2017/18E as it transitions fuel and US$ lease cost increases. FCF yield remains positive at ~10% (2017/18E). In E Europe, we see Wizz poised to accelerate share gains as smaller competitors suffer disproportionately from cost rises. Our PT of €22.5 implies ~13x 2017/18E PER – for a share trading at less than 11x PER.”

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Air France-KLM – “2017 does not look constructive for European airline profits overall. We see a likelihood that profits fall before they get better - as a hangover of excess capacity growth needs working off before higher fuel prices can eventually (2018) rein in supply growth. For AFKLM, we see 2017E profits falling but positive FCF.”
Deutsche Lufthansa AG – “With 36% equity in the EV, once profits do start improving, Lufthansa shares could perform well – but that point is not yet. Our ~3% higher 2017E adjusted EBIT is down 14% YoY. 2017 needs to clear the supply hangover of 2016; pilot cost (in Lufthansa) needs resolution; and Eurowings has to prove it can be profitable (as well as big).”
Ryanair Holdings – “Base case Ryanair forecasts support a €17-€18 share with ~20% upside. Should fare declines lessen from -10% (RBCe) 17/18E, upside would increase. If -10% is right, Ryanair should outperform its peers (where fare attrition forecasts at 4-6% will be too low). If fare decline is closer to 5%, 17/18E EPS will be ~20% higher, creating upward PT pressure.”

BE11:57am

............ And Davy doing the same.

BE11:58am

We are now more constructive on industry fundamentals for
the first time in four years. Capacity growth trends in short-
haul and key long-haul markets are improving. There are also
signs that the unit revenue backdrop is getting better, which
we find interesting as yield assumptions across the sector are
now very conservative. These underpin our ‘Outperform’
ratings on IAG and Lufthansa. Separately, our detailed overlap
analysis of the European short-haul market supports our
structural long view on Ryanair. We think that easyJet now has
big decisions to make – is it a dividend yield or growth stock?
We cut our rating to ‘Underperform’.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Slowing capacity growth on key European routes

Our analysis shows slowing rates of growth on the main short-haul and long-haul European markets, with short-haul growth decelerating for the first time since 2012 (to 5-6%) and the northern transatlantic seeing easing growth to similar levels from 8% in 2016. While these levels are still high in absolute terms, the directional move is important for sector valuation.

Pricing inflection point coming? It has already happened in the US Demand indicators now have positive momentum in continental Europe and the US.

Following a difficult 18 months, we think the long-haul carriers will soon hit an inflection point in pricing. This has already happened in the US, with improved close-in yields seen at all three major US-based carriers in December. Those most exposed to positive trends are IAG and Lufthansa.

Short-haul network analysis; easyJet’s strength is its Achilles heel

Our detailed bottom-up analyses of Europe’s low-cost carrier (LCC) networks suggest that part of easyJet’s pricing weakness is due to increasing competitive overlap, e.g. its airport-pair overlap with Ryanair has tripled since 2014, all driven by Ryanair. easyJet generates the highest EBIT per operating base of Europe’s LCCs – it is somewhat vulnerable to encroaching competition from other LCCs. Separately, we think step-changes in Ryanair’s network structure (airport mix; frequency; business-friendly scheduling) should drive continued demand benefits. Ryanair, IAG and Lufthansa our preferred names

Our preferred names for 2017 are Ryanair, IAG and Lufthansa with price targets of €16, £6.1 and €15 respectively. Meanwhile, leverage and competitive concerns mean that we downgrade both Air France-KLM and easyJet to ‘Underperform’. We maintain our ‘Neutral’ ratings on Wizz Air and Norwegian, which have exciting business models but look fairly priced.

BE12:00pm

Goldman on IAG, however, remains elusive.

BE12:00pm

If I remember right, I think it says "it's cheap".

12:00 pm

11:27 am
PM11:27am

It's like talking to competition lawyers. All a competition lawyer in the UK wants to do is break the 30% rule and/or the four competitors standard
